resource.name: persistent_identification_of_elements_in_procedural_shape_modelling
resource.keywords: persistent identification, procedural shape modelling, selection operation, 3D CAD.

abstract.p: This document defines standardized representations for the persistent identification of explicit model elements.

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 provides generic resources for the identification of explicit model elements in procedural shape modelling. The constructional operations themselves are represented by entity data types defined in other parts of ISO 10303, interpreted as constructors. Procedural models have the advantage of being easy to edit, simply by changing values of parameters used as arguments of their construction operations. A procedural model is represented by a sequence of construction operations that include various form feature manipulations such as creation, separation, deletion, etc. Explicit model elements are to be selected for the creation of each form feature. ISO 10303-55 [2] specifies the resource constructs for the identification of explicit elements. As an extension of ISO 10303-55, this part of ISO 10303 provides resource constructs for the persistent identification of explicit elements. The persistent identification is useful for finding explicit elements of a post-edit model corresponding with those of a pre-edit model.

imgfile.title: Schema level diagram of relationships between the topology_based_identification_schema of this part of ISO 10303 and other resource schemas

resource.scope: This part of ISO 10303 provides generic resources for the persistent identification of explicit model elements in procedural shape modelling.

inscope.li: the persistent identification of faces in a procedural model by using their construction history;
the persistent identification of edges in a procedural model by using the persistent identifications of the adjacent faces;
the persistent identification of vertices in a procedural model by using the persistent identifications of the adjacent faces.

outscope.li: the specification of modelling commands and sequences of modelling commands;
the representation of dimensions and constraints;

definition.def:
mechanism to assign unambiguous identification to an element of an explicit shape model in terms of the procedural operations used to generate the explicit model.
The concept of persistent identification in this part of ISO 10303 is only intended for the identification of shape elements generated during the generation of an explicit model from a procedural shape model. It is not related to requirements in other parts of ISO 10303 for the identification of data, such as PDM metadata, and the need to unambiguously identify the same data over time between different iterations and re-publication of the data.

introduction.p: The subject of the topology_based_identification_schema is the persistent identification of elements of a procedural model. Persistent identification will permit consistent retrieval of elements when regenerating the procedural model thus facilitating the exchange of parametric 3D models. The topology_based_identification_schema is used to identify elements of a procedurally produced solid model.
This schema provides representation methods for the following:
― the persistent identification of indicated elements in a procedural model.

p.b: 4.2.1 Persistent identification in a procedural solid model

fund_cons.p: Detailed shape models created by feature-based CAD systems include form features, constraints, and parameters in addition to B-rep model data. Feature-based CAD systems represent shape models by a hybrid method containing both a procedural model and an explicit model. The procedural model is represented in terms of the operations used in a modelling session. In feature-based CAD systems, a shape model is represented by a combination of form feature data and B-rep data.

B-rep elements are generally associated with modelling operations. Each form feature is generated by referencing geometric and/or topological entities of the existing B-rep model, and the resulting B-rep model can be referenced later by other form features. In this context, a mechanism for persistently identifying a topological element is necessary. In particular, the persistent identification is valuable when finding the same topological element in the new model (post-edit model) corresponding to the referenced topological element in the old model (pre-edit model).

p.b: 4.2.2 Basic identification of topological elements when generating a form feature

fund_cons.p: When a form feature is generated, basic identifications, or names, are given to topological elements of the form feature based on feature type, sketch, and path information, as shown in Figure 2. In this part of ISO 10303, basic identifications of faces are determined first and the identifications of edges and vertices are determined using the identifications of related faces. Details for basic identification are dependent upon form feature types. The basic identification of an edge uses the basic identifications of 2 adjacent faces, the basic identification of a vertex uses the identifications of at least 3 adjacent faces.

figure.title: Basic identification of topological entities of a form feature

p.b: 4.2.3 Ambiguity resolution when generating a form feature in an existing intermediate model

fund_cons.p: After a form feature is generated, it could be modified during subsequent procedural modelling operations. During these operations, merging or splitting of topological elements could occur. Merging or splitting of topological elements results in an ambiguity as shown in Figure 3. Merging of topological elements leads to loss of some basic identifications. Splitting of topological elements leads to the situation where two or more topological elements have the same basic identification. Split element information (SEI) and merged element information (MEI) are added to basic identifications of topological elements in order to resolve these ambiguities. SEI provides information for resolving the ambiguity when element split occurs, and MEI provides additional information for resolving the ambiguity when elements are merged.

figure.title: Ambiguity arising from merging or splitting of topological elements

tech_discussion.b: E.1 Table showing relationship between entities in this part of ISO 10303 and ISO 10303-111
tech_discussion.p: This annex is to provide a table to show correspondence between entities defined in solid_shape_element_schema of ISO 10303-111 and entities defined in topology_based_identification_schema of this part of ISO 10303 (ISO 10303-57). There are cases that two or more entities in ISO 10303-57 are required to fully cover an entity in ISO 10303-111. The entities defined in ISO 10303-111 are construction operations that can be used in procedural shape modelling. The faces to be created from a construction operation in the table can be persistently identified by the corresponding entity or entities mapped in the table.
tech_discussion.note: Some of subtypes of and defined in ISO 10303-111 that do not require explicit profile as an attribute are not directly supported in this part of ISO 10303. However the identification of faces generated by the above construction operations can be supported if they are treated as a profile based feature inside a generating system.

There are cases that some additional blend faces are generated when one of , , or is created with a particular value of floor blend radius. The identification of the additional blend faces cannot be supported by this part of ISO 10303, unless the faces are treated as a separated edge blend feature inside a generating system.

table.caption: Relationship between entities in this part of ISO 10303 and ISO 10303-111

examples.b: F.1 Example of intended usage of the topology_based_identification_schema
examples.p: This annex contains an example illustrating the intended use of the persistent identification capabilities defined in this part of ISO 10303 for modelling the shape of a product. The current result model is assumed to be an ISO 10303-203 [3] model that precedes the procedural representation in an ISO 10303-21 [1] exchange file. The example shows the use of entity data types defined in ISO 10303-111 as constructors. The modelled form is an L-shaped block with a hole and an edge blend on it.

In this example, it is assumed that the procedural model entries are preceded by an explicit representation of the model, summarized by the instance #840. The instance of associated with the explicit model is #850.

Instance #1010 defines the dual model relationship between the explicit and procedural representations of the L-block. The file fragment contains three occurrences of composing the procedural representation, instances #1030, #1170 and #1310. Note that the above file fragment does not contain the whole geometric and topological information defining the explicit model of the L-block, instead it provides a part of supporting information for construction operations.

example.p: Instance #1040 represents an operation for creating a , the base shape of the L-block (Figure F. 1 (b)). One of the attributes of that instance is the to be protruded (Figure F. 1 (a)). Instance #1210 represents an operation for creating a , the shape of the hole in the block (Figure F. 1 (d)). One of the attributes of that instance is the to be pocketed (Figure F. 1 (c)).

After instance #1040 has created the protrusion forming the basic shape of the L-block, and #1210 has created the pocket on the L-block. After that, the concave edge of the resulting volume is selected and an operation for creating a performed on it by instance #1360 (Figure F. 1 (e)).

Note that the selection operation is indicated in the sequence of operations by an instance of defined in this part of ISO 10303 (Figure F. 1 (b) and (d)). This refers to the selected element which are topologically identified during the procedural modelling, and determines the appropriate use of that element in the succeeding operation. Note that the entity was used to select the elements such as a face or an edge which are topologically identified in the procedural model, instead of directly selecting geometric elements by using defined in ISO 10303-55.

examples.p: All other instances in the procedural part of the example, except one, are of entity data types defined in this part of ISO 10303.

note.p: This example does not contain the information for ambiguity resolution such as split or merge information.
